fields.title: National COVID-19 Convalescent Plasma Project
fields.body:
The Mayo Clinic has been named the national site for Convalescent Plasma Expanded Access
Program and will be the lead institution providing coordinated access to investigational
convalescent plasma for hospitalized patients with severe or life-threatening COVID-19, or those
at high risk of progression to severe or life-threatening disease.
The program grew from a national initiative of physicians and investigators from over 40
institutions who self-organized to investigate the use of convalescent plasma during the
COVID-19 pandemic. These institutions include Mayo Clinic, Johns Hopkins University,
Washington University, Einstein Medical Center, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai,
Michigan State University (see more information about individual locations below).
To donate, the general requirements are:
● You must have been symptom-free for a period of time, usually at least 14 days.
● If you have tested positive for COVID-19, you will need to show that you now have a
negative test. You can begin that process yourself by contacting the organization that
tested you in the first place. Some locations that take plasma may be able to provide the
COVID-19 test, but most will not.
● If you think you had COVID-19, but did not actually have a positive test, the donation site
will likely test your blood to see if you have antibodies to the virus, which will tell you
whether you were infected with the virus in the past
● Donation sites may request that you wear a mask while donating.

fields.title: Tufts University COVID-19 Convalescent Patient Registry
fields.body:
This registry will connect you to research studies in your area or from around the country
conducted by researchers at major academic institutions, non-governmental organizations and
biopharmaceutical companies. Tufts Clinical Translational Science Institute is hosting a research
registry under the direction of Andreas Klein, MD collecting information on persons who have
recovered following an infection with the SARS-CoV-2 virus that causes the illness called
COVID-19.  If you choose to be entered in this registry, you will be asked to complete an initial
survey regarding your COVID-19 illness experience and how likely you would be to want to take
part in certain types of research activities.

fields.title: Red Cross Plasma Donation
fields.body:
The Red Cross is establishing a program to work with clinicians on providing such convalescent
plasma, as needed. You must have fully recovered from COVID-19, and have antibodies in your
plasma that attack the virus. Donated convalescent plasma will be tested and analysed as
potential treatment for patients seriously ill with COVID-19.

fields.title: Biological Specialty Company
fields.body:
BSC is seeking donors of blood or plasma from those who have an ACTIVE COVID infection as
well as people who are recovered. They have mobile units that will come to you.

fields.title: Collaboration Developing Potential COVID-19 Hyperimmune Therapy
fields.body:
Leading manufacturers of plasma-derived therapies have formed an alliance to develop a
hyperimmune immunoglobulin that can be used to treat the COVID-19 virus. The partnership
was initiated by Takeda and CSL Behring, and are joined by Biotest, BPL, LFB, and Octapharma.
The companies will devote their own resources to the effort and also plan to collaborate with
government and academic groups on a number of activities including clinical trials.
They are working immediately on developing an unbranded treatment that will have the
potential to treat individuals with serious complications from COVID-19. They are in need of
plasma donations from people who have fully recovered from COVID-19 and whose blood
contains antibodies that can fight the novel coronavirus. Once collected, the “convalescent”
plasma would then be transported to manufacturing facilities where it undergoes proprietary
processing, including effective virus inactivation and removal processes, and then is purified into
the product. It may be possible to donate plasma to more than one facility.

fields.title: American Association of Blood Banks
fields.body:
Many blood donation locations are beginning to collect convalescent plasma from recovered
Covid-19 patients, but their websites have not been updated and due to the emergency situation,
they have not been able to get the word out to the public. A listing of accredited blood donation
sites in the USA is available below. Please find the location nearest you and call to see if they are
accepting plasma donations.
